Stem: Alpha Standardized Science G7.9 Created By STC 11 Lava Lamp Station: Answer questions when at station. Plate Tectonics Station : Answer questions at sea-floor spreading station. Density Density- amount of mass (number of atoms) in an area More Dense: Hallway during bell change Less Dense: Hallways when classes are in session When an objects heats up, it becomes less dense. When an object cools down, it becomes more dense. Lava Lamp Station: Answer questions when at station. Plate Tectonics Station : Answer questions at sea-floor spreading station. Convection Currents Reference: https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/outreach/lesson_plans/Convection%20Currents.pdf Lava Lamp Station: Answer questions when at station. Plate Tectonics Station : Answer questions at sea-floor spreading station. Lava Lamp Convection currents also occur in lava lamps. We will use a lava lamp to represent what happens inside Earth. Earth's core causes temperatures to rise, which makes rock in mantle less dense. The density of the hot rock is less than the material above it, so it begins to rise. The rock hits the solid lithosphere and cannot rise any further. The rock begins to cool near the crust and becomes less dense. Gravity causes the more dense material to fall back down towards Earth's core. The cycle repeats. Scientists believe this constant motion causes the tectonic plates to move apart, crash together, or slide past each other. These movements result in new land features like mountains and trenches being created, earthquakes, and volcanic eruptions. Lava Lamp Station: Answer questions when at station. Plate Tectonics Station : Answer questions at sea-floor spreading station. Stem: Brass Experiment Eric performs an experiment in class with a brass ball and ring. He starts with both the ball and ring at room temperature (22oC). When both the ball and ring are at room temperature, the ball easily slides through the brass ring. Eric then places the brass ball only over a flame and keeps it over the flame for 2 minutes. As soon as he removes the ball from the ring he tries to place it through the brass ring, but this time the ball does not slide through the ring. Which of the following statements explains why the ball no longer fits through the ring? Select two correct answers.
Choices: A) group of scientists measured several water quality parameters to better understand how dead zones in the Gulf of Mexico impact brown shrimp populations over time. The scientists are most interested in the dissolved oxygen levels because the levels are critical for the survival of brown shrimp populations. Brown shrimp populations thrive when dissolved oxygen levels in the Gulf of Mexico are greater than 2 mg/L. However, the populations cannot thrive when dissolved oxygen levels are at or below 2/mg/L. E As thermal energy was removed from the brass ring, it contracted. F As thermal energy was removed from the brass ring, the particles lost kinetic energy. Use the stimulus material and your knowledge of Science to answer the following questions. Dead Zone In the spring of each year, the second largest dead zone in the United States forms in the Gulf of Mexico. During the spring, farmers fertilize their land as they prepare for crop season. As a result, nutrients from the fertilizers, such as nitrogen and phosphorus, drain into the Mississippi River and eventually the Gulf of Mexico. According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, “Excess nutrients that run off land or are piped as wastewater into rivers and coasts can stimulate an overgrowth of algae, which then sinks and decomposes in the water” (NOAA, 2018). The decomposition process consumes and depletes oxygen levels in the Gulf of Mexico, which causes hypoxic areas or dead zones.

Category 4 Hurricane In less than a week, Katrina had become one of the most powerful Atlantic storms on record, with winds in excess of 170 mph. On the morning of August 29, the storm made landfall as a Category 4 Hurricane near New Orleans, Louisiana. The winds, heavy rains, and 26 feet high ocean waves caused a lot of damage and flooding. In New Orleans, which is mostly below sea level, federal officials thought the city had “dodged the bullet” (escaped harm). While New Orleans didn’t get a direct hit by the intense winds of the storm, the true threat was seen quickly. The levee system that held back the waters of Lake Pontchartrain and Lake Borgne had been completely overwhelmed by 10 inches of rain and 26 feet ocean waves. Key Recommendation: Add a real-world phenomenon or puzzling scenario that students need to figure out. Require students to engage in a science practice (analyze data, construct explanation, argue from evidence).
